section.title: net-info
section.para: Displays basic information for a virtual network

entry.para: The name or UUID of the virtual network to display information for.

example.screen: virsh # net-info default Name default UUID 1c42888c-82c9-4dda-bc9c-4387962a0c0e Active: yes Persistent: yes Autostart: yes Bridge: virbr0
example.para: Displays basic information for the virtual network named "default".
If the host server is running Linux, then the Bridge field gives the name of the Linux network bridge being for the virtual network.

example.screen: virsh # net-info --network default Name default UUID 1c42888c-82c9-4dda-bc9c-4387962a0c0e Active: yes Persistent: yes Autostart: yes Bridge: virbr0

listitem.para: We begin with an existing virtual network, running on the host:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-list --all Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes
listitem.para: The virtual network "default" is active and enabled for automatic starting.
We use the net-info command to display further details:
listitem.screen: # net-info default Name default UUID 1c42888c-82c9-4dda-bc9c-4387962a0c0e Active: yes Persistent: yes Autostart: yes Bridge: virbr0
listitem.para: Some of the same information can also be retrieved using the command, then looking through the output:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-dumpxml default <network> <name>default</name> <uuid>1c42888c-82c9-4dda-bc9c-4387962a0c0e</uuid> <forward mode='nat'/> <bridge name='virbr0' stp='on' delay='0' /> <ip address='192.168.122.1' netmask='255.255.255.0'> <dhcp> <range start='192.168.122.2' end='192.168.122.254' /> </dhcp> </ip> </network>

listitem.para: - Outputs the XML configuration for a virtual network, to stdout.
- Lists the virtual networks livirt is aware of
